content: Total nonfarm employment declined steadily between December 2007 and October 2009, dropping from 137,951,000 to 129,633,000, with the majority of job losses occurring after November 2008. An input-output (I-O) model is often used to estimate the number of jobs created by economic activities due to its cost-effectiveness and ability to show interrelationships between industries. An input-output (I-O) model illustrates the distribution of dollar value across industries in the production process, showing the origin of purchased products. For example, it can show how roof trusses from one industry and bricks from another are used in construction. This information is then used to determine employment requirements.
